twitch_info.title: I Wanna Ponder - 100% | Full Playthrough (Part 1/9)
twitch_info.description:
0% -> 43%
The start of the playthrough. Just getting a feel for various puzzles and experimenting with stuff.

there's a LOT of different kinds of color blindness so color adjustment is a lot more finnicky then symbols which would universally work for every kind of color blindness

so you can start this one by removing the leftmost column, you just have to figure out how much more you want to toggle
i just dont get why theres 2 colours
the main thing you want to do is try and remove corners or lone tiles
see like that last move left that remnant in the bottom left, that's the kind of thing you don't want to do
see the idea there is that you used a move for that and could toggle it off with another rectangle but you could've just toggled the section off with two rectangles anyway
so its usually not a useful move
return of the russian penis man was decidedly exciting
if i knew how to explain this everything would go better
the idea is kind of if you have an L shape like this, turning that on just gives you a square to remove which takes two moves
but locks you into that square concept
if you remove the two sections of the L individually you have more power because you have more control over what else you can include in those moves to maximize them
yeah that's generally how it goes
suddenly the dancing mushrooms dont feel as helpful as they were in the beginning of the game FeelsBadMan
but when you do that you want to be removing things from the edges and reintroducing stuff in the middle for the most part
they will help you if u acept that they are chickens
maybe if i walk you through one with logic to see how the thinking pattern works?
who'd put a dancing chicken in their stream that makes no sense
sounds like something casual would do
yeah its not even really complicated, it just requires a really uncomfortable thought pattern for most people i think
too many required iq points for me to do all of this
i dont get why there's 2 colours
if this was 1 colour id understand
yeah the 2nd color makes a big difference because it opens up move complexity that isn't just a rectangle
so you want to remove the first column in the first move
and the second column in the second move
the one with 2 on and 3 off
like you want it all off after your first move
so your first move would be 0,0 to x,1
so the next move is to get rid of the second column
well right, you don't just want to get rid of the second column
you have to assess those and extend right to see what other useful things you can make out of it
so for instance, you could've also removed the entire bottom row with the 2nd move
right, but you can see how this is reducing the rectangle shape
mind you these moves aren't entirely right
but now if you look at this, what could you have done differently to make two rectangles, since with 2 red/blues it has to be two overlapping perfect rectangles
i almost think i understand this. the song is helping
so re-do the second move for a sec
you know, as the designer, you're not great at explaining this
so if you look at this one, you can see that you'd probably want to be able to clear out the extensions, in this case you see a nice alignment on the bottom row
i mean, it is very hard to explain, i highly doubt anyone else can rly explain better or more clearly
i imagine someone has to be able to
i'm bad at explaining things in general
so you'd look to make a rectangle that cleans up that bottom row and forms another rectangle

or vice-versa you'd want to make a rectangle that cleans up the left and forms another rectangle, but that's such a mess that it doesn't seem reasonable (which makes you think that's what you needed to fix)
but your options are essentially doing a 3 by 1, a 3 by 2, a 3 by 3 or a 3 by 4
like that's looking fairly rectangular right now
so if you think back to what you did do
is there a way you could've made that a full rectangle
the general idea is the first move has more power
you don't want to make isolated parts
i think i got a way to understand it more, gonna have to play to see if it works
and the dangerous thing is it takes a bit of foresight
so the correct move here is 0,0 to 3,1
so the one with just the left spike in it
is you're looking at the second move
and feel like you're going to have to turn that one isolated one on in the process
so in doing this you can see the rectangular outline assuming you're doing that
its kind of a two-step move
i'm afraid of it tho if needle placements becomes a big deal
if you turn on easy mode there shouldn't be anything problematic at all
there's a couple stages with a little bit of awkward needle placement but this stage shouldn't really have any
try to take out two birds in one stone again
it kind of requires a habit of looking to simplify and eliminate in the same step
this is a 3x3 overlayed on top of a 4x3
you're looking too hard at the encompassing rectangle
i think i got a visualization technique that helps
i'd love to hear it too since clearly mine doens't seem to help people
i like treating the rectangles like panes of different colored glass stacked on one another and it makes more sense to me
i'm not sure if it helps any but you can also think of anything thats off as an even number and anything thats on as an odd number
and that's how many times you need to hit them with a move
but you can kind of see that the concept doesn't really change
